articles.description: This work is part of the international cooperation extension project entitled - Preservação do Potencial Produtivo das Zonas Produtoras de Algodão no Mali - Cotton Solos-, developed in partnership by the Federal University of Lavras, the Brazilian Cooperation Agency and the Compagnie malienne pour le développement du textile (CMDT), Koutiala, Mali.
articles.contents:
About the Authors
Luciana Sanches
Dr. Sanches graduated with a degree in Sanitary Engineering from the Federal University of Mato Grosso, Brazil, a master’s degree in Sanitation, Environment and Water Resources from the Federal University of Minas Gerais, a PhD in Road Engineering, Hydraulic Channels and Ports from Universidad de Cantabria, Spain, a post-doctorate degree in Environmental Physics, Brazil, and a post-doctorate degree in Environmental Sciences from the University of Reading, United Kingdom. She specialized in workplace safety engineering and in project development and management for the Municipal Water Resources Management by the National Water Agency.
Lattes ID: http://lattes.cnpq.br/2358137001200356
Marcelo de Carvalho Alves
Dr. Alves is associate professor at the Federal University de Lavras, Brazil. His education includes master’s, doctoral, and post-doctoral degrees in Agricultural Engineering at Federal University of Lavras, Brazil. He has varied research interests and has published on surveying, remote sensing, geocomputation and agriculture applications.He has over 20 years of extensive experience in data science, digital image processing and modeling using multiscale, multidisciplinary, multispectral and multitemporal concepts applied to different environments.
Lattes ID: http://lattes.cnpq.br/1691831453683402

articles.title: Monitoring Interest Areas in Bandiagara II Using Geocomputation and Geotagged Photos
articles.description: Welcome to the website. I hope you enjoy it!
articles.contents:
Work presentation
The Village Bandiagara II is part of the Zangasso commune in the Cercle of Koutiala in the Sikasso region of southern Mali. Basically, it is composed of desert and semi-desert areas, which has a well-defined climatic seasonality with a marked drought.
On February 15th, we walked around the perimeter of the village, recording the route on a walking line with Garmin Forerunner 235 GPS measurements , and simultaneously recording geottaged photos using the Iphone 12 mini cell phone (Ilustration in figure 1).



Figure 1: Ilustration geotagged photo.



Using R and R packages: dplyr (Wickham, François, et al. 2022), ggplot2 (Wickham, Chang, et al. 2022), leaflet (Cheng et al. 2021), leafpop (Appelhans and Detsch 2021), lubridate (Spinu et al. 2021), purrr (Wickham, Henry, and RStudio 2023), readr (Wickham et al. 2023), sf (Pebesma et al. 2022), tibble (Müller et al. 2022), tidyr (Wickham and RStudio 2020), and exifr (Dunnington and Harvey 2021).
This walk is the delimitation of the georeferenced area, making it possible to recognize the place by recording topographic information, land cover and use, the interactions between the residents of the rail such and the neighboring tribes, understanding the use of construction elements and its surrounding environment and, therefore, exploring the potential to reveal interesting areas and their underlying space-time dynamics to improve the quality of health and sanitation.
